captions.text:
Here's a word that perfectly
describes the way the car

industry has evolved over
the past 15 years.
Niche.

Making an impact these days is
as much about finding some

unoccupied space in the market
as is it is competing with
established competition.

So just about everything
is a niche nowadays.

In fact, there are so many
niches and sub-niches--

SUVs, SAVs, CCs, and
well, WTFs--

that they almost blend into
one homogeneous whole.

And suddenly a Ford Mondeo
seems rarer than an

uncontroversial Lewis Hamilton
tweet because within all those

niches, no one actually makes
saloons or sedans anymore.

Unsurprisingly, a cool-looking
low rider from AMG with silly
performance is a great car.

But I get the feeling that the
shooting-brake format could be

a massive hit, especially
in Europe.

With a 557-horsepower
V8 it's mental.

But even with a 200-horsepower
diesel, much of this car's

appeal will still
shine through.
Good times at Mercedes.
So this is the latest niche.
The CLS63 shooting brake.
Hm.
A pretty obvious recipe now.

A big 5.5-liter bi-turbo V8,
which in this particular

machine has 557-horsepower,
531 foot-pounds of torque.

I'm not entirely sure whether
you can get more torque in
this thing.

Because you can't, from launch,
buy the engine in the

lowest state of power tune,
which is about 525-horsepower,

because apparently everyone
said they wanted the big,
faster engine anyway.

So they didn't bother doing
the small engine.

Weighs about 60 kilograms more
than a standard CLS.

And, in the UK, is about 83,000
pounds before you've

thrown lots of money's worth
of paint and interior.

But we can talk about
that in a minute.

Because this car does look
reasonably spectacular.

It is, in many ways, the
least surprising car
I'll drive this year.

Because you know what
you're going to get.

You've got a lot
of performance.
And you've got--
[TIRES SQUEALING]
a lot of that.

But of course, it's endlessly
surprising because it's not so

much pace, and it's
got so much space.

And it's just unbelievable how
much fun you can have in such
a big car these days.
We get so used to it--
Yeah.
It's an interesting recipe.

So I suppose the question is,
first of all, does the CLS
need another niche?

Is the shooting brake just
rather stepping on the toes of
the E-class estate?

Or does it feel like rather
a special little car?

I'm sort of leaning towards the
latter, it has to be said.

This is a lovely,
lovely machine.

It feels a bit more bespoke, a
bit more special with this

lower roof line, the narrower
window glass line.

It just feels like you're
in something a
bit out of the ordinary.
Not a normal car.

But yet it's got
so much space.

I think the decision to make
this car a five-seater was a
little bit inspired.

The middle seat in the
back is not big.

That's the one, that's the
naughty step, really.

If your child's behaving badly,
that's the one that
goes in the middle.
But it's entirely usable.

And it does open the
car up for a whole
new audience, I think.
Sounds strange, doesn't it?

We're talking about niches
within niches and opening up
to a new audience.

This car has the feel,
potentially, of
being a bit of a cult.
It's got unique style.
It's got crazy performance.

This one with the locking diff
will do, yeah, two black lines
pretty much anywhere.

So as a package, really
interesting car.

I have a few observations
on the dynamics.

Does it feel very similar
to the standard CLS?
Of course it does.

60 kilograms is not
that noticeable.

It might feel a little
less agile.

And the weight is right
over the back axle.

So on the one hand, that
helps with traction.

On the other, yes, it probably
makes the car feel
a little less lazy.

But these are not small,
little, nimble
sports cars, are they?

They're great big muscle
cars that happen
to be built in Germany.

This car does have the
optional limited-slip

differential, which I think
transforms the way you can get
the car round the corners.

Without this diff, the thing
just wants to light up all the
traction control.

Actually, with the diff, you
can leave it in Sport mode,

gives you a bit of slip, and
both wheels hook up.

It makes it really
quite impressive.

Only a little 2.85 section
at the back running 531
foot-pounds of torque.

That's a lot of torque for each
of those bits of rubber.

And when you overcome
them, yeah.
Things get smoky.

Gearbox is really quite
good if you
just leave it in Comfort.

Of course, this Mercedes
MCT 7-speed is
actually a doctored automatic.

It's not like a double-clutch
gearbox.

So it does mean that when you
use it in manual mode, you do

have to just wait a little
bit for each
change to come through.

But that just doesn't
worry me at all.

Because in Comfort, in Normal
mode, it's a really nice

automatic with a nice
amount of creep.

And it just allows this car at
low speed to feel like quite a

low-performance car when
you want it to.
Doesn't mean it's boring.

And of course, it's
always burbling
and making that noise.

In that respect, AMG have
kind of got BMW a bit
licked at the moment.

Because their cars feel quite
spectacular at low speed and

make very few demands
of the driver.
Inside, loads of room.

Very nice cabin design,
I have to say.

Not for me to judge what looks
right and wrong, or good or

bad, but to me personally,
this is a great place.
And it's high-quality as well.

Mercedes is back to making cars
that feel really, really
expensive inside.

Don't know about you, but within
the sort of discipline

of practical performance, I've
always preferred estate cars.

Because if you're gonna make
the leap to have four doors

and a load of performance,
why not have a
massive boot as well?

Because it just adds to the
absurdity of how much poke

you've got and how usable
your car is.
This is a nice balance.

The boot itself is actually
quite big.

All too often when companies
make these shooting-brake-y

coupe-ish type cars,
they end up being--

because the design's a bit
contrived and a bit difficult,

they end up being less practical
than the car on
which they're based.

And then you think, well,
what's the point?

But this actually offers a
really useful extra amount of
room over a CLS.
The boot is really big.

And also, if you dig around
underneath the boot floor,

there's a load of space
in there as well.
It's got some lovely touches.

This one's got the operational
Bang & Olufsen hi-fi with a

great big amplifier in the boot
and a subwoofer which

will rattle your fillings
whenever you want to.
Are there any downsides?

Well, it's big and it's heavy
and it'll chew consumables.

I had the brakes pretty much on
fire a minute ago chasing

this lovely bloke in his
997 Turbo S. It uses
quite a bit of fuel.

Although I have to say, compared
to the previous

normally aspirated V8, this is
much more fuel efficient
because it's got stop-start.

You don't have to try so hard
to make the thing move,

because of all that
torque low down.

One other observation, the
steering does have quite a lot
of soft centering on it.

Obviously, there's not much
coming back at you.
It's very accurate.

But I noticed that just on those
last couple of degrees,

when you want to just release
your grip on the wheel and

just let the wheel feed back
into the center, it moves a

little bit quicker
than expected.

Throttle response is
really quite good.

It doesn't really matter how
quickly the turbos spool up

because the thing appears to
just have urge everywhere.

I mean, I don't know
whether it's got an
anti-lag system or what.

But it is remarkable how
much poke it's got.

Just put your foot down like
that and away you go.
I love these things.

They're just faintly ridiculous,
aren't they?

It's a big, practical car with
massive performance.

It costs an awful lot of money
and yet it offers an awful lot
of ability.

If there's any type of car that
deserves to be worth a

lot of money, it's this one
because it can do so much for
so many people.

title: AMG CLS 63 Shooting Brake. Niche Car Porn - /CHRIS HARRIS ON CARS

comments.text:
A little off topic, but I'm 6'5 and my buddy got a CLA250 and I LOVE LOVE 
LOVE that car, he got it in a deep purple that almost appears black but 
then catches the sun and it looks so cool, has aggressive styling, tail 
lights to die for, front end that makes you stop and stare, and a ton of 
kick for a 2.0 litre turbo with 200hp. The steering is good, everything is 
lovely, but then I had to get into it, recline the seat all the way, and 
slide down into it to even see stoplights. Too damn low :'(
But if anyone is in the market for a $35,000 (canadian) car and is under 
6ft I'd highly recommend it :) I just wish they weren't so damn small...﻿

comments.author: Sandra Rios

comments.text:
This has four doors, a hood that is relatively short compared to the cabin, 
and the driver sits well forward of the rear axle- in my opinion it's not a 
shooting brake, its an estate with a cut roof line.  Mercedes are just 
calling it a shooting brake for marketing reasons, without seeming to have 
any understanding of what the term means.

comments.text: I'll get it for you sweet cheeks
comments.author: Luna Tuna

comments.text:
Gosh, ow biased can one be. You compare the back room for luggage with a 
CLS  SEDAN? Well duh, offcourse would the Shooting Brake have more room. 
What were you trying to sell here? You should compare the back room with 
any other luxury Wagon/Estate. If you would have been honest you would have 
said that the Shooting Brake has the tiniest amount of room of them all 
(Audi/BMW/Merc E class, etcetera)!  There's a reason for that, but that's 
not the gist of this reply. It's your dishonest nonsensical comparison, and 
in general one heck of a biased, no-critics whatsoever, way of presentation.

If you would have had any integrity in this review you would have mentioned 
the tiny cheap 7"nav screen (for this luxury category). You should have 
demonstrated the lack of space for luggage compared to other wagons. And 
you should have demonstrated and mentioned the lack of height for the 
passengers in the rear seat. And finally you would have mentioned and 
demonstrated the lack of visibility around you and through the back of the 
window.

The proper conclusion would be that one would buy one heck of a cool wagon 
for quite some money after some needed upgrades, but you have to give up 
quite a few basic things:
- significant (!) loss of space for the luggage-height
- you'd have the smallest luggage space compared with other midsize wagons
- rear seat height (a six foot person is going to have a significant 
problem)
- visibility around you and through he back window
- cheap tiny nav screen.

I've testdriven this thing myself and that's how I found out. The coolness 
and driving characteristics are undisputable but in a review you gotta 
mention the negatives you know.﻿
comments.author: A Freethinker

comments.author: Chilibe

comments.text:
In this case it simply means a car category that is non-mainstream, with 
little to no competition.
A car that is not one of the classic types like a 3 box design sedan or 
something the like. 
Generally, niche has a meaning similar to gap.
